label: real
article:
Quarantine before family gatherings, take sore throats seriously and don’t overestimate the immediate effect of a vaccine: Virologist Christian Drosten’s advice for the corona winter. 

Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch.
The number of new infections is rising, but Germany can still make it through the winter without things getting too bad, says virologist Christian Drosten of Berlin’s prestigious Charité University Hospital. Is it OK to sit inside a restaurant when the weather gets cold? Or go ahead with the party you've planned? Things now hinge on the small, everyday decisions we make. And on whether everyone plays along. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Even though novel coronavirus infections are rising faster than they were in June, you seem – following your media break over the summer – more relaxed. Are looks deceiving?
Christian Drosten: Looking at the course of the pandemic puts me in a state of anxious attentiveness. We are in a period where there are no major problems on the medical side – and by that, I mean overcrowded hospitals and intensive care units – but also one in which we need to make sure that it doesn’t get that far. With this virus, you have to react early. You can see this by comparing Germany and Britain, two countries that are structured similarly. Germany simply implemented measures earlier in the spring. That has resulted in fewer infections and fewer deaths in this country so far. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Do we still have the reins in our hands in the current phase?
Drosten: Absolutely. The question is: What kind of buffer do we have if we start seeing an increase in severe cases because a growing number of elderly people are getting infected again? At the moment, there is still a significant buffer when it comes to clinical care. But elsewhere in Europe, we can see that the hospitals have filled up again, for example in the south of France or in Madrid. It is up to us to keep that from happening.
ZEIT ONLINE: The federal government together with the German states just adopted new rules and warned that they will enforce existing measures more stringently. If the number of new infections in a district exceeds 35 per 100,000 inhabitants, stricter rules for festivities and gatherings will be applied. Steps are also being taken to strengthen the public health authorities. Will these moves suffice to get through the autumn and winter without an explosion in the numbers of cases?
Drosten: It's impossible to say; we’ll have to wait and see. It certainly makes sense to limit the size of groups in closed, indoor spaces because that reduces the probability of super-spreading events, in which one individual infects many others. But with such rules, it doesn’t take long before you run into uncertainties. It raises questions like: How large can a group be? And what about the length of the stay or the height of the room? I recently attended an event on a factory floor. The ceiling was so high that it was practically like being outside. 
ZEIT ONLINE: That means that certain values have to be set arbitrarily?
Drosten: Exactly, and that is the difference between science and politics. A politician has to pragmatically say: "This is where we draw the line."
ZEIT ONLINE: The most important criterion for introducing more stringent measures remains the number of new infections reported. But not every infection leads to a serious illness. That’s why scientists like Hendrik Streeck are calling for other criteria to be given more weight, such as the number of hospital admissions or the test positivity  rate – factors that are already being considered in Austria. Do you think that would make more sense than the current hotspot strategy?
Drosten: It is true, of course, that not every COVID-19 case is equally relevant to the spread of the pandemic or in medical terms. Case mortality varies greatly between age groups. On average, old people die much more frequently after falling ill with COVID than young people, who have been particularly susceptible to infections in recent months. So, I think it’s understandable that people would like to have an additional indicator like hospital bed capacity. My objection here is that the new infections themselves are already a lagging parameter. 
ZEIT ONLINE: What do you mean by that?
Drosten: The diagnosis has a delay of a week, and in some overburdened laboratories it takes a little longer. This means that a patient who is diagnosed with the coronavirus today is an indicator of the extent to which the virus was circulating in society a week ago. And the lagtime for bed occupancy is even greater, because patients often don’t have to go to the hospital until the week after the diagnosis. One possibility for a further criterion would be to not just count the number of infections, but to also keep a separate count of the number of people infected who are over the age of 50. Using those figures, you could accurately predict how many severe cases are on the horizon. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Many people moved their social lives outside over the summer. As winter approaches, that's no longer quite as easy to do. Chancellor Angela Merkel has thus emphasized once again how important is the behavior of each individual. What tips do you have beyond general hygiene like social distancing, regular hand washing, wearing a mask every day or better room ventilation?
Drosten: It’s important that we all work together and understand that it’s up to us. If we do, we'll act wisely, even when no one is looking. It comes down to many small, everyday decisions. For example, when you go out to eat and the question comes up as to whether or not you should move inside even though it is quite crowded. Do you go in or do you say: "Yeah, it's cold, but let's sit outside for another 15 minutes and then go home." Or the question of whether you really have to throw that party you had planned this winter, whether you can perhaps find an airy, extra large room for it or postpone it until next year. None of these things are forbidden and nobody can or wants to regulate them. We have to all take the situation seriously even as we are trying to have a normal everyday life. We all have to develop the appropriate situational awareness. 
ZEIT ONLINE: What is your strategy? Do you still go to restaurants?
Drosten: Unfortunately, I don't manage to go out to dinner too often at the moment because I don’t have time. But I'm happy to sit outside, even when it’s a little colder. 
ZEIT ONLINE: What will happen at Christmas, when all of Germany goes to visit the family and also comes into contact with the grandparents? What can be done to make things a bit less risky?
Drosten: I think the idea of a pre-quarantine is a good idea. That means people would avoid social contacts to the degree possible for a few days, or ideally a week, ahead of the family visit with grandma and grandpa. Each individual, of course, has to consider how this can be implemented in their own everyday life. How do you do that when you have children who go to daycare or school? And is it possible to avoid meetings for a few days before the family visit or to work entirely from home if your job allows for it? 
Then you can go to your relatives with the thought in the back of your mind that, with fewer contacts, you probably didn’t get infected this week. If at all, you may have been infected the week before, in which case it is unlikely that everyone in the family would remain free of symptoms. This could be an approach for the coming period – for the upcoming fall holidays and perhaps also for Christmas. But the same applies here as well: To a certain extent, people have to weigh up the risks in a pandemic on their own. There is no absolute safety – there are always residual risks. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Surveys show that more people in Germany again believe that they are at high risk of infection. At the same time, fewer people claim they are abiding by the rules for hygiene, like washing their hands regularly, social distancing or wearing a mask. Do you have understanding for the fact that some people have become less disciplined or just can't be bothered anymore? 
Drosten: Yes, that’s totally human. And things like that also happen in certain situations, like when people are under the influence of alcohol. I can also understand that things lose their urgency and that over the summer, the situation wasn’t taken as seriously because the disease wasn’t as visible. But a look now at other European countries shows that the situation could get difficult again. Perhaps we should be looking more closely at the southern hemisphere, which has just made it through winter. Take Argentina, a country with a similar age structure to Germany, which has had trouble controlling the pandemic despite a lengthy lockdown. 
ZEIT ONLINE: In addition to individual behavior, the sensible use of tests is also important. Politicians are currently revising the national testing strategy for Germany. Are you involved in that effort?
Drosten: I might be asked my opinion here and there. And if not, it's just fine. I’m totally replaceable. I don’t expect to see the testing strategy for the first time until it is published. 
ZEIT ONLINE: What do you think the testing strategy should include?
Drosten: My mantra is that we should test people who have corona symptoms. I don’t reject all reasons for testing asymptomatic people or for mass testing, but we can’t test everyone. We can’t expect that we will be able to further expand PCR test capacity (Eds. Note: PCR is shorthand for the most commonly used coronavirus test). We could even see a reduction in capacity due to a lack of materials available – not only the reagents, but also the disposable elements like the plastic parts. That’s why we need to direct testing to where it is more likely to detect the disease. This helps the public health authorities in contact tracing as well as the individual patients themselves. And in cases of positive tests, the family doctor needs to keep track of those patients to prevent the seriously ill from getting to the hospital too late. 
ZEIT ONLINE: What else do you think should be included in the testing strategy?
Drosten: I think it's important to find a threshold that distinguishes between infection and infectiousness. One that not only shows whether a person is infected, but also whether that person is contagious. This is very important for the public health authorities, for example, and will surely be implemented in the test strategy. 
ZEIT ONLINE: And how exactly do you identify this threshold?
Drosten: We now know pretty clearly that infected people are contagious for about one week after the first symptoms: through epidemiological observations and because in the laboratory, one week after the onset of symptoms, the virus can only be cultured in one-fifth of all samples. A panel of experts that is reviewing the studies available could pragmatically agree on a threshold value based on that data. A person would not be considered infectious below that threshold, but they would be above it. There will probably be a corridor in between, a gray area where it isn’t clear. "Likely infectious," "gray area" or "probably not infectious at the time of specimen collection" could be part of all future lab reports. 
ZEIT ONLINE: And what about alternatives to the PCR tests, the only laboratory method currently available that can reliably analyze swabs?
Drosten: Many alternatives are currently being discussed, including LAMP tests – a special variant of the PCR procedure – or mass sequencing, that are interesting. They are not, however, being discussed for this pandemic and no longer for this winter. The main reason is that these tests still have to be done in the laboratory. It isn’t testing that you can bring to the patient, where the test is taken and analyzed at the same place. But such tests are exactly what we need. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Rapid antigen tests are a great hope for the future. How good do you think the tests are that are coming onto the market now?
Drosten: This is a great development. These simple antigen tests work much better for SARS-CoV-2 than they do for the flu, for example. This is likely because infected people have a lot of virus in their throats. At my institute, like other labs in Germany, we are currently busy validating these tests. We are testing products from various firms. Quality is still fluctuating somewhat because production processes are only just being set up. Overall, though, these tests work well. Although they’re not as sensitive as a PCR, they test positive in the range in which people are likely to still be infectious.
ZEIT ONLINE: That means antigen tests could soon help to distinguish whether a person is contagious or not?
Drosten: If things go well, it is possible they will. That would be great, it would be practical in many different situations. But I cannot yet say for sure. I’m not sure if the validation of the antigen tests from several laboratories will be available by mid-October in time for the new testing strategy. It’s also unlikely we will be finished by then determining the viral load at which a person is still contagoius. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Where do you think antigen tests could be deployed most effectively?
Drosten: The main aim is to make an acute diagnosis in patients with symptoms. That’s the most important thing. People have a lot of virus in their throats when they have symptoms, even if they are only mild. In such cases, you could determine that if a person has symptoms but the antigen test is negative, that person does not have COVID-19. I would likely have confidence in such a statement in the near future, once the data is a bit more solid than what I am seeing now. If positive, the result of the antigen test would have to be confirmed with a PCR test, if only for reporting reasons.
ZEIT ONLINE: There has also been talk of using antigen tests at the entrances of nursing homes to determine whether someone is allowed to visit their relatives. These people usually have no symptoms, but a test would have to reliably detect whether they are infectious. 
Drosten: On the one hand, we now know that asymptomatic cases don’t excrete less virus – at best they’re just contagious for a shorter period of time. So, I assume that asymptomatic cases would also test positive with an antigen test. Once the tests have been validated and the laboratories have a clear picture of what they do, these tests can be an asset, particularly for nursing homes, especially since there are medical personnel there who can perform the test. However, it is important in such cases that it not be seen as a diagnosis, but as a momentary estimate of contagiousness. One solution would be to specify that the negative test result is only valid for the duration of the visit and that it expires after that. Regardless, it remains important to wear a mask, socially distance and adhere to the hygiene rules.
ZEIT ONLINE: Such tests don't necessarily change the situation for cultural events or for clubs and bars. And home testing that normal people can administer themselves also aren't likely in the immediate future. 
Drosten: Rapid coronavirus tests would first have to be approved for home use. And I am hearing from experts that such a validation will take time. The biggest problems are with administering them: Even if the quality of the tests is sufficient, you still have to make sure that people use them correctly – that they do the throat swab correctly, for example. That can’t be implemented very quickly, so we have to find a pragmatic approach. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Capacity could be another problem. How many antigen tests will be available in Germany per month?
Drosten: From what I’m hearing, it will be in the millions, not just three, but probably also not as much as 20. The question is what happens if other countries have the same needs? Will enough tests be available then? We already encountered those problems with the PCR tests. One thing is certain though: We won’t be able to simply test our way out of the pandemic. That is merely a thought experiment which may be academically appealing, but it is not workable. It seems much more important to me to keep the population informed. This includes explaining once again that most infected people do get symptoms and what they can feel like. Even though we have already achieved a great deal through the dissemination of information, lack of knowledge about the disease is still widespread. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Whose responsibility do you think that should be?
Drosten: Political leaders, above all. I think it’s good that Chancellor Angela Merkel went before the camera and talked about a gradual doubling of the caseload. I would also like to hear politicians say: It's likely that 80 percent of all adults do show symptoms, if you count runny noses and sore throats. Please pay attention. And if you do exhibit such symptoms, stay home. A word from very high up has wide reach, and the messages are simple. But it is important that they are sent. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Shouldn’t family doctors also be doing more to educate people?
Drosten: Yes, absolutely. Still, I am sometimes rather surprised that when it comes to educating patients, family doctors aren't universally supportive. Some individual practitioners apparently don't think that protective measures like mask wearing are important, and even actively undermine them in some cases. Family doctors and pediatricians have close relationships with their patients and should be using them to spread the message that we all have to pull together. For the benefit of vulnerable patients, in particular, we need to inform people and explain things to them once again. 
ZEIT ONLINE: By that you mean older people who still have particular trust in their family doctors?
Drosten: Yes, the data confirms that mortality from COVID-19 increases markedly with age (MedRxiv: Levin et al., 2020). It is a virus that is extremely dangerous for people in the last 10 years of their working life – it cannot be compared with influenza at all. And for people in their first 10 years of retirement, it must absolutely be avoided. These people must not get infected. This age group needs to internalize this and I don’t think that has happened to a sufficient degree yet. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Which debate about the virus itself seems most important to you at the moment?
Drosten: The idea that the virus will weaken in the near future is not one that I support. There has been one mutation that apparently gave the virus a big boost in strength. But this D614G mutation happened in the earliest days of the European epidemic and has now spread worldwide. According to the data available, the potency of the virus hasn’t changed, only its ability to spread, although only minimally. And this is how it is likely to stay in the near future. If, by chance, a virus weakens – by losing a gene, for example – there is always a competing virus in the vicinity that will prevail within a short amount of time. As such, it’s unlikely that a weakened version of the pathogen will establish itself very soon. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Other pandemic coronaviruses have apparently weakened over time to the point that they tend to only cause mild colds now. Will that also be true of SARS-CoV-2?
Drosten: That’s quite possible, but if it does, it will only happen long after the pandemic, when population niches have developed in many countries of the world and the virus only spreads locally. In such isolated niches, a weakened virus can appear that can spread easily, but which isn't as pathogenic. This happened with the other coronaviruses, but it took decades. But the stability of SARS-CoV-2 also has an advantage: We don’t need to fear that the virus will soon mutate to the point that a vaccine will lose its effect.
ZEIT ONLINE: Regarding a vaccine. Do you still anticipate seeing one or more of them on the market in the course of the next year?
Drosten: Yes, but a distinction has to be made between 
"approved" and "on the market." The first vaccines may even be approved 
by the end of the year. But the question is how many people you can 
inoculate. At first it won’t be that many. That’s why people with a risk
 of severe illness as well as health workers are likely to get 
vaccinated first. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Many experts believe that the first-generation vaccines are unlikely to protect against infection. Do you agree?
Drosten: They are more likely to protect against a severe form of the disease than against the infection itself. However, data from experiments with primates also suggests that vaccination reduces the viral load in the throat (for example: New England Journal of Medicine: Corbett et al., 2020). So, I doubt that the virus will spread unhindered under the cover of the vaccination. I also expect that the not-so-great first-generation vaccines will play their part in helping to control the pandemic. If you have enough of them. 
ZEIT ONLINE: That won’t be the case at first. How should we imagine this transitional period?
Drosten: There will be a juxtaposition next year. We will have different vaccines, which may even have differing efficacy, and parts of the population will be vaccinated with them. At the same time, contact restrictions and the basic hygiene rules will still be important. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Do you have the feeling that this information has already been sufficiently communicated?
Drosten: No, my feeling is that this information hasn’t been conveyed yet. That includes telling people that the vaccines may not be perfect. It could be that they don’t provide sufficient protection or that there are side effects that stand in the way of recommending them for younger people, who tend not to fall seriously ill. I think we need to start preparing people now for a vaccine that may not be perfect. The time has now arrived. It would have been premature earlier because the Phase III trials are only just starting. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Is our strategy overly focused on a vaccine?
Drosten: It is buttressed by a vaccine, but nothing more. It doesn’t depend on it. Even if we were to see that for some completely inexplicable reason the development of a vaccine were to fail, we would still rely on measures like social distancing. Otherwise, the virus would force us to implement tough countermeasures again simply because it is not tenable to allow this disease to run its course in a society with our age profile. As such, the past and present measures are not up for debate. 
ZEIT ONLINE: You have had extensive interaction with politicians during the pandemic. How has this changed your view of things?
Drosten: I have gained an insight into how long it can sometimes take for something to get decided and the regulatory hurdles that there are. It might surprise you how long things can take, even during a pandemic. But there is no way of accelerating things if all democratic ground rules are adhered to.
ZEIT ONLINE: What has changed most for you personally?
Drosten: I get recognized on the street all the time and hope that this will pass at some point. I still feel it was the right decision to become a public face like this because you can achieve a lot by educating people. But I’m not the kind of person who wants to continue to remain in the limelight. I don't want to use this as a springboard for some kind of television career in the near future. On the contrary, I hope this pandemic will end as soon as possible and that I can resume concentrating on my normal work. And I hope that people will then forget about me, that in a few years’ time, newspapers will write a "Where Are They Now?" story about Christian Drosten.
ZEIT ONLINE: You have also said that you have received threats. How do you deal with them?
Drosten: It differs widely. With some mails, you think: He’s a nutcase. There are some where I feel sorry for the author, even though that person is flooding me with aggression. And there are the few really malicious and psychologically manipulative mails. Fortunately those are quite rare. 
ZEIT ONLINE: On the other hand, the majority of Germans support the current measures, in which you have played an active role. You were even awarded the Order of Merit, Germany’s highest civilian honor. What does that mean to you?
Drosten: The most important thing for me is really that most people agree with the measures – even if it could always be more. But, of course: The fact that the German president awarded me and others, like the pianist Igor Levit and the science journalist Mai Thi Nguyen-Kim, the Federal Cross of Merit is a clear indication that people think what we are doing is right. That reassures me in those moments when I am being attacked. It makes me realize over and over again that I am doing the right thing. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Still, there are some who see you as a prophet of doom. Do you do enough to spread hope?
Drosten: Yes, of course! I'm not at all a pessimistic scientist, that is just an imputation. It's just the end result of some distillations, but it isn't the reality. We have a realistic chance in Germany of getting through the autumn and winter better than many other countries. But what Ms. Merkel has done recently by pointing out repeatedly that now is our opportunity to get the situation under control and tamp down the virus is absolutely right. You can't let things go, only to later – perhaps too late – step in. 
Translator: Daryl Lindsey
